Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2010 12:46PM leisaparis wrote: Yes definately reschedule. I also had the same kind of discharge. I have IBC. I first noticed it @ 2 months before other symptoms, didn't pay it any mind, was going through first stages of menopause. If you don't get it checked out right away, and for some reason you develop anymore symptoms, please go get it checked out. The reason I checked mine out was because my right breast started changing in many ways. Other women only have 1 symptom. so please don't wait to long. It's better to be safe than sorry. Good luck and god bless........Leisa
Posts.Title: Dark reddish brown nipple discharge 46andhopeful leisaparis

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 01:13PM leisaparis wrote: lorieg...arm above your HEART(propped up on a pillow), not head, or I would be in the same position with 2. Is suppose to help with the draining. That's what it sayes in the paperwork they gave me anyway. Question...for anyone who has already had surgery. Did any of you get bandaged up afterwards or did they just leave you open with no bandages? They left me open with no bandages. Was wondering how common this was. Any replies would be appreciated. Also since they took all the nodes out of the right, can't have anything stuck in or on right side anymore. So they put the IV in the left. However they couldn't put it in the elbow crease or the back of my hand so they used my wrist. I had 3 fingers go numb the whole time the IV was in. They said it had nothing to do with the IV, BUT when they took the IV out all 3 fingers got the feeling back in them. So if this happens to any of you just know the feeling will come back after they take out the IV. Good Luck to all you going in this week. As soon as it's over you'll feel so much better.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 10:05PM leisaparis wrote: Hi Ladies, Thought I would join you. I had a bilateral mastectamy yesterday(April 8th). Aggressive on the right with all the nodes and I opted to have them take the left and one node to check for cancer just for my satisfaction. I have IBC and did not want to go through this again. I also have 2 drain tubes. One for each side. Surgery went fine, no pain meds till I got ready to go home. All the moving around I think. Picked up pain meds for home. Will have Herceptin for a year and radiation for 31 treatments. Had chemo for 24 weeks before surgery. Also checked the packing and preparing forum to know what to take and have ready at home. Extra pillows for bed..to sit up. Open in front larger shirts. I also got a camasole, but where the elastic hits, landed right on the drain sights. That hurt. Took that off and went to the bigger shirt. feels a lot better. Slick P.J.'s to ease in and out of bed. Hope everyone having surgery this month has an easy time of it. Good Luck to all. Leisa

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 06:45PM leisaparis wrote: My patient advocate person sent me over to the physical therapist before surgery to get all the excercises I would need to do after surgery. I recieved all the above plus @ 10 more. Most are to be done at least 10 repetitions/ 3 times a day. Some you have to have a stick to do. Most want you to use the bad arm(as the pushing/pulling arm) to get it back into shape. The one I feel the most tension from is the arm swing. You bend over with good arm resting on a table, with the bad arm pointed toward the floor, swing the arm clock-wise (10 times)then counter-clock-wise(10 times). Reaching for the floor. I also have the wall slide, shoulder roll, arm curl, plus a few more. The therapist also showed me a thing to do to my sides to keep the lymph fluid flowing. I had all the ones on the right removed, she said this was something I would have to do the rest of my life. It's really simple, you just start at your hips, palms in, place on hips and push down and out. You then move up your sides all the way to your arm pits ( I have to use the back of my hands when I get close to the top...cuz I'm fat). After that, you put your hands at the top(arm pits) and push all the way down to the hips in one motion. Like I said it's suppose to help keep the lymph fluid moving. Since it's very simple, I will be doing it. Sure don't want anything clogging up the fluid. Sure don't want lymphodema. Hope this helps. Good luck all.  Leisa

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 08:01PM leisaparis wrote: Hi everyone, Going in the morning to see the surgeon, to take out the tube on the right. It leaked a couple of times more. I remember the dr. doing something to it when he took the left one out so I tried it. It helped, I had a clog. Then I read some more of my paperwork. It's called milking the tube. You hold the tube at the top with one hand and pull on it with the other. It stretches the tube allowing the clog to pass. You do this all the way down to the bulb part of the tube. Then within a little bit the clog was in the bottom of the bulb. What a relief. I just wish they would have said something to me either when I got out of the hospital or at least when he removed the left one to remind me. Since then no leaks. Thank goodness. Have a good evening everyone.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2010 12:43PM leisaparis wrote: Hello gals, I know I haven't written in a while. Have been trying to get back into the work routine, while doing radiation. I have had a bad time with radiation. I didn't have this much trouble with all the chemo I took and am still taking. They had to use what the call a bolus(sp) on me everyday. It's to keep the radiation to the top of the skin. Gave me 3rd degree burns everywhere the radiation went. Can only use sylvadine(sp) cream on it. Glad I still have no feeling under the right side or it would hurt like hell. Can feel my collar bone and front of my chest and those spots hurt bad enough. I'm completely raw and since I finally had my last treatment (Thursday the 24th) it is trying to heal. Now it cracks and bleeds though. Not sure which is worse, the use of the bolus or the cracking and bleeding. Glad that part is over. Anyone else having that kind of problem? Hope everyone has a better day than me.   Leisa

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2010 06:28PM leisaparis wrote: got silky pj's at wal-mart. not to expensive. really does help with the sliding in and out of bed. took a robe, didn't wear it either. nice and soft so will keep it. family & friends of mine from work and home gave me some stuff for the hospital stay. used some of it, had more than I needed. didn't wear 1/2 of it. all nice stuff. will wear it later. most of it pink of course, which is fine, I don't mind. I was not told to bring anything specific to the hospital. didn't get any bandages over breast and didn't have to wear anything to go home in. when I saw the dr. on Monday I asked. he said I didn't need anything I was doing fine.guess it all depends on your surgeon.
